sections.title: Introduction (Wide Shot)
sections.content: Welcome back, I’m Jihad Al Sayed. Today we’re linking two powerhouse ideas — eigenvectors and linear transformations. This is where math meets motion, geometry, and computer graphics.

sections.title: How Transformations Work
sections.content: A linear transformation maps vectors from one space to another using a matrix. But not all vectors change the same way — some just scale without changing direction. These are eigenvectors.

sections.title: The Equation Again
sections.math: A \vec{v} = \lambda \vec{v} → \text{This means } \vec{v} \text{ is unchanged in direction under the transformation A}

sections.title: Visualizing Transformations
sections.content: Imagine dragging a shape across the screen — eigenvectors are the directions that stretch but don’t rotate. In animations or simulations, these anchor points are crucial.

sections.title: Example: Transformation in Graphics
Real-World Applications
sections.content: Used in face recognition, 3D rendering engines, deep learning layers, and physics simulations. Eigenvectors help preserve key structure in transformations.

sections.title: Recap
sections.content: Today we saw how eigenvectors behave under linear transformations and why they’re the ‘stable directions’ that make math predictable, visual, and powerful.
